title: Tech Equipment Redistribution Across Regional Hubs

The goal is to minimize total distance while balancing workloads across depots and respecting time constraints.

title: Urban Grocery Delivery with Returnable Packaging
content: A grocery chain uses multiple distribution centers (<loc_depot>) to deliver perishables (<demand_linehaul>) in reusable containers to urban customers while collecting empties (<demand_backhaul>) for restocking. Vehicles must first drop off groceries before picking up packaging, never exceeding load capacities (<capacity>). Routes terminate at the last delivery/pickup point, and all trips must finish within a 6-hour window (<time_limit>) to ensure freshness and same-day service.

title: Mobile Charging Station Deployment and Retrieval Network
content: A tech company operates depots (<loc_depot>) across a city to deploy portable EV charging stations. Trucks (<capacity> units) must first deliver new stations to high-demand locations (linehaul), then collect used or low-battery units from other sites (backhaul). Routes must complete all tasks within an 8-hour shift (<time_limit>), ensuring no capacity overloads. The goal is to minimize travel distance while adhering to duration limits and open-route constraints.

title: Temporary Construction Storage Delivery and Retrieval Network
content: A logistics firm manages decentralized depots (<loc_depot>) to deliver storage containers to active construction sites (linehaul) and retrieve empty ones from completed projects (backhaul). Trucks have a `<capacity>` container limit and must finish routes within 10 hours (<time_limit>). The challenge is optimizing delivery-pickup sequences, preventing overloads, and avoiding depot returns after the final stop.

title: Urban Recycling Bin Deployment and Material Collection Network
content: A city’s recycling program requires deploying new bins (<loc_customer>) and collecting filled ones using multi-depot (<loc_depot>) trucks. Each vehicle holds up to `<capacity>` cubic meters. Routes must first deliver empty bins (linehaul) before collecting recyclables (backhaul), completing within a 7-hour window (<time_limit>). The aim is to balance loads, minimize travel, and ensure all stops are served without depot returns.

title: Mobile Office Space Setup and Retrieval Logistics
content: A corporate services company deploys modular office furniture from regional depots (<loc_depot>) to remote workspaces (linehaul), then retrieves used setups (backhaul). Trucks (<capacity> units) must complete routes within 9 hours (<time_limit>). The focus is on efficient sequencing, capacity management, and finalizing deliveries/pickups without requiring trucks to backtrack to depots.

title: Disaster Response Communication Equipment Deployment and Recovery
content: During emergencies, a tech firm uses multi-depot (<loc_depot>) fleets to deliver satellite communication units (linehaul) and recover damaged devices (backhaul). Vehicles carry `<capacity>` units and must finish routes within 12 hours (<time_limit>). The priority is rapid response, capacity adherence, and completing all stops without depot returns post-last delivery/pickup.

title: Offshore Research Vessel Supply and Sample Collection Network
content: A network of marine research stations scattered across coastal regions requires regular supply deliveries and sample pickups. Multiple depots (`<loc_depot>`) along the coast dispatch research vessels with a maximum cargo capacity of `<capacity>` tons. Each vessel must first deliver critical supplies (e.g., fuel, equipment) to remote stations (`<loc_customer>`) with specific demands (`<demand_linehaul>`), then collect scientific samples (e.g., water, sediment) for analysis (`<demand_backhaul>`). Routes must end at the final station (open routes) and adhere to strict duration limits (`<time_limit>` hours) to avoid exceeding fuel reserves or missing research deadlines. The challenge is to balance depot assignments, prevent overloading vessels, and minimize total travel distance while ensuring timely sample retrieval for urgent analysis.

title: Urban Vertical Farming Equipment Delivery and Compost Retrieval
content: A city’s vertical farming initiative uses multiple depots (`<loc_depot>`) to supply modular hydroponic systems to rooftop farms (`<loc_customer>`). Each truck carries a maximum load of `<capacity>` kg, delivering equipment (`<demand_linehaul>`) and then collecting compost waste (`<demand_backhaul>`) from farms. Routes must conclude at the last farm (open routes) and finish within `<time_limit>` hours to comply with urban curfews and ensure fresh deliveries. The goal is to optimize routes across depots, avoid overloading vehicles, and minimize travel costs while maintaining compost collection schedules for recycling facilities.

title: Disaster Preparedness Kit Distribution and Salvage Material Retrieval
content: In regions prone to natural disasters, a network of emergency depots (`<loc_depot>`) must distribute preparedness kits (`<demand_linehaul>`) to vulnerable communities (`<loc_customer>`) and later collect salvageable materials (e.g., building debris) (`<demand_backhaul>`). Vehicles have a `<capacity>` ton limit and must operate within `<time_limit>` hours to prepare for potential disasters. Routes are open-ended, ending at the last stop, and prioritize depot efficiency while ensuring all communities receive supplies and salvageable items are retrieved for recycling.

title: Cruise Ship Provisions Delivery and Waste Management Logistics
content: A maritime logistics company operates from multiple coastal depots (`<loc_depot>`) to supply cruise ships (`<loc_customer>`) with perishable goods (e.g., food, bottled water) (`<demand_linehaul>`) and collect waste materials (`<demand_backhaul>`). Each truck has a `<capacity>` ton limit and must complete routes within `<time_limit>` hours to align with ship schedules. Routes are designed to end at the final ship docking port (open routes), avoiding detours that could exceed capacity or time constraints. The challenge is to balance depot assignments, prevent overloading, and ensure timely service to maintain cruise operations and environmental compliance.

title: Renewable Energy Wind Turbine Maintenance and Scrap Metal Collection
content: A wind farm operator uses regional depots (`<loc_depot>`) to dispatch trucks with `<capacity>` kg capacity for turbine maintenance. Vehicles first deliver replacement parts (`<demand_linehaul>`) to scattered wind farms (`<loc_customer>`) and then collect broken components (e.g., blades, gears) (`<demand_backhaul>`). Routes must end at the last turbine site (open routes) and finish within `<time_limit>` hours to minimize downtime. The goal is to optimize depot-based routing, prevent overloading, and ensure scrap metal retrieval for recycling while maintaining energy production efficiency.

title: Satellite Equipment Deployment and Retrieval for Remote Research Stations
content: A network of polar research bases (`<loc_depot>`) must deploy scientific instruments to remote Arctic field sites (`<loc_customer>`) while retrieving outdated equipment. Each vehicle has a `<capacity>` ton limit for transporting both new gear (linehaul) and obsolete hardware (backhaul). Routes must prioritize deliveries before pickups to ensure operational readiness. Researchers require `<demand>` kg of equipment per site, and retrieval demands vary by station. Vehicles operate under a `<time_limit>` hour duration constraint to avoid extreme weather exposure, ending routes at final destinations without returning to depots.

title: Offshore Oil Rig Supply and Scrap Metal Retrieval Network
content: Offshore supply hubs (`<loc_depot>`) service oil rigs (`<loc_customer>`) by delivering machinery parts (linehaul) and collecting scrap metal (backhaul). Each vessel’s `<capacity>` tonnage must balance outbound supplies and inbound recyclables. Rigs demand `<demand>` kg of equipment, while scrap pickups depend on operational waste. Routes must adhere to tidal windows (`<time_limit>` hours) to ensure safe return to base, but vessels finish at their last rig to await further instructions.

title: Urban Solar Panel Installation and Recycling Logistics
content: Solar installation firms use `<loc_depot>` warehouses to deploy new photovoltaic panels (linehaul) and collect decommissioned panels (backhaul) from rooftops (`<loc_customer>`). Trucks `<capacity>` limits restrict carrying both heavy new panels and fragile used ones. Each site requires `<demand>` kW of new panels and generates `<demand>` kg of recyclable material. Routes must complete all deliveries before pickups and stay within `<time_limit>` hour work shifts to comply with urban curfews, ending at final customer locations.

title: Mountain Rescue Equipment Distribution and Used Gear Recovery
content: Alpine rescue teams distribute emergency kits (linehaul) to remote mountain huts (`<loc_customer>`) and recover outdated gear (backhaul) using `<loc_depot>` base stations. Vehicles must carry `<capacity>` kg of supplies and retrieved equipment. Each hut needs `<demand>` liters of oxygen and `<demand>` kg of returned gear. Routes must respect `<time_limit>` hour travel limits due to altitude restrictions, concluding at the last serviced hut to await evacuation needs.

title: Temporary Flood Barrier Installation and Salvage Logistics
content: Flood response teams deploy `<loc_depot>`-based vehicles to install sandbags and pumps (linehaul) at flood-prone areas (`<loc_customer>`) while retrieving damaged debris (backhaul). Each vehicle’s `<capacity>` limits require balancing deployment and salvage loads. Sites demand `<demand>` cubic meters of barriers and `<demand>` kg of waste. Routes must finish within `<time_limit>` hours to avoid rising water levels, ending at the last barrier site to monitor flooding risks.

title: Mobile Library Book Delivery and Return Collection Network
content: A network of regional library hubs (`<loc_depot>`) operates mobile delivery vehicles to distribute new books to community centers (`<loc_customer>`) and collect returned materials. Each vehicle has a `<capacity>` limit for carrying both outgoing books (linehaul) and incoming returns (backhaul). Routes must first complete deliveries before pickups, ending at the final stop (open routes). Drivers must finish their routes within a `<time_limit>` workday shift, ensuring efficient utilization without overtime.

title: Urban Streetlight Maintenance and Component Recycling
content: City maintenance crews from multiple depots (`<loc_depot>`) deliver repair parts (e.g., bulbs, sensors) to faulty streetlights (`<loc_customer>`) and collect defective components for recycling. Each truck can carry up to `<capacity>` kg of materials. Routes must prioritize deliveries before pickups, end at the last serviced location (open routes), and complete within an 8-hour shift (`<time_limit>`). This balances workload across depots and minimizes waste.

title: Offshore Research Vessel Supply and Scientific Equipment Retrieval
content: A marine research organization uses coastal depots (`<loc_depot>`) to supply equipment (e.g., sensors, sampling kits) to offshore research vessels (`<loc_customer>`). After missions, vessels return scientific samples (backhaul) to the nearest depot. Vehicles must not exceed `<capacity>` kg, deliver supplies first, and finish routes at the final drop-off point (open routes). Trips must conclude within a `<time_limit>` to align with vessel schedules.

title: Livestock Health Monitoring and Vaccine Delivery with Sample Retrieval
content: Veterinary teams from regional depots (`<loc_depot>`) deliver vaccines (linehaul) to farms (`<loc_customer>`) and collect blood samples (backhaul) for disease testing. Each vehicle carries `<capacity>` liters of supplies and sample containers. Routes must first vaccinate livestock before collecting samples, end at the last farm (open routes), and finish within a `<time_limit>` workday to ensure timely lab analysis.

title: Agricultural Seed Distribution and Soil Sample Collection Network
content: Farm cooperatives distribute seeds (`<demand_linehaul>`) to farms (`<loc_customer>`) from multiple depots (`<loc_depot>`) and collect soil samples (backhaul) for nutrient analysis. Vehicles have a `<capacity>` limit for seed bags and sample containers. Routes must deliver seeds first, end at the final farm (open routes), and complete within a `<time_limit>` to align with planting seasons. This ensures efficient resource use and soil health monitoring.

title: Maritime Cargo and Waste Recycling Logistics Network
content: Shipping companies operate from multiple coastal depots (`<loc_depot>`) to deliver essential goods (e.g., food, fuel) to remote island communities (`<loc_customer>`). Each vessel has a maximum cargo capacity of `<capacity>`. After delivering linehaul shipments (demand `<demand_linehaul>`), vessels must collect recyclable waste materials (backhaul `<demand_backhaul>`) from the same communities. Routes are open-ended, terminating at a designated port hub, with a strict duration limit (`<time_limit>` hours) imposed by fuel and crew endurance constraints. The challenge is to balance cargo and waste loads without exceeding capacity while minimizing total voyage distances and adhering to time limits.

title: Rural School Textbook Delivery and Used Material Collection
content: A regional education authority uses `<loc_depot>` distribution centers to supply new textbooks (`<demand_linehaul>`) to rural schools (`<loc_customer>`) and collect outdated materials (`<demand_backhaul>`). Each delivery van can carry up to `<capacity>` kg of combined textbooks and recyclables. Routes must prioritize textbook deliveries before initiating waste pickups. Open routes end at the final school on the itinerary, with a duration limit (`<time_limit>` hours) to ensure all deliveries are completed before the academic year begins. The goal is to optimize routes for fuel efficiency while avoiding overloading vehicles.

title: Offshore Wind Turbine Maintenance and Component Recycling
content: Maintenance crews operate from coastal depots (`<loc_depot>`) to service offshore wind farms (`<loc_customer>`). They deliver replacement parts (`<demand_linehaul>`, e.g., turbine blades, gears) and retrieve decommissioned components (`<demand_backhaul>`). Each service vessel has a `<capacity>` ton payload limit. Routes must first deliver parts before collecting waste materials, ending at the final wind farm or a secondary depot. A duration limit (`<time_limit>` hours) ensures operations stay within safe daylight or tidal windows. The aim is to minimize travel distances while respecting capacity and time constraints.

title: Global Electronics Distribution and E-Waste Repatriation Network
content: An electronics retailer uses `<loc_depot>` hubs across continents to deliver new devices (`<demand_linehaul>`) to retail stores (`<loc_customer>`) and collect obsolete products (`<demand_backhaul>`) for recycling. Containers have a `<capacity>` unit limit for both shipments. Open routes end at final destinations (e.g., regional warehouses), with a duration limit (`<time_limit>` days) imposed by shipping lane schedules and perishable battery lifetimes. The challenge is to plan efficient routes that avoid overloading containers and meet global sustainability targets.

title: Medical Research Sample Transport and Lab Equipment Retrieval
content: A global research consortium deploys `<loc_depot>` field labs to deliver lab equipment (`<demand_linehaul>`) to remote research sites (`<loc_customer>`) and collect biological samples (`<demand_backhaul>`). Each transport vehicle has a `<capacity>` kg limit for sterile equipment and perishable samples. Routes must first deliver equipment before returning to collect temperature-sensitive samples. Open routes conclude at the final field site, with a strict duration limit (`<time_limit>` hours) to preserve sample viability. The goal is to minimize logistical costs while ensuring sample integrity and equipment availability.

title: Space Station Module Logistics and Waste Management
content: Astronauts on a space station require regular resupply missions and waste disposal. Multiple launch facilities (`<loc_depot>`) dispatch spacecraft to deliver equipment/supplies (`<demand_linehaul>`) to orbital modules (`<loc_customer>`) while retrieving experimental waste or decommissioned hardware (`<demand_backhaul>`). Each spacecraft has a payload capacity `<capacity>` and must complete missions within a strict duration limit `<time_limit>` hours due to fuel constraints. Routes are open-ended, ending at designated disposal zones or research stations, ensuring no return to the launch depot until mission completion.

title: Deep-Sea Research Equipment Deployment and Sample Retrieval
content: A marine research consortium uses submarines (`<capacity>`) launched from coastal depots (`<loc_depot>`) to deploy scientific instruments to underwater observation sites (`<loc_customer>`) and collect biological samples (`<demand_backhaul>`). Each mission must adhere to a maximum dive duration `<time_limit>` to ensure crew safety. Submarines start at depots but may end routes at remote research platforms, prioritizing linehaul deployments before backhaul collections to avoid overloading.

title: Desert Conservation Water Delivery and Wildlife Monitoring
content: A conservation team operates from multiple desert base camps (`<loc_depot>`) to deliver water and food (`<demand_linehaul>`) to wildlife refuges (`<loc_customer>`) while retrieving motion sensor data pods (`<demand_backhaul>`). Vehicles must not exceed `<capacity>` (due to limited storage in rugged terrain) and complete routes within `<time_limit>` hours to avoid extreme temperatures. Routes terminate at remote data hubs rather than returning to depots, optimizing fuel use for harsh environments.

title: Underground Mining Equipment Distribution and Ore Retrieval
content: A mining operation uses electric trucks (`<capacity>`) from surface depots (`<loc_depot>`) to deliver machinery and safety gear (`<demand_linehaul>`) to tunnel work sites (`<loc_customer>`) while hauling extracted ore (`<demand_backhaul>`). Routes must be completed within `<time_limit>` minutes to ensure battery life and worker safety. Trucks operate as open routes, ending at ventilation shafts or processing stations instead of returning to depots, minimizing underground travel time.

title: Arctic Research Station Supplies and Data Collection
content: Researchers in the Arctic rely on ice-resistant vehicles (`<capacity>`) departing from coastal depots (`<loc_depot>`) to deliver fuel and equipment (`<demand_linehaul>`) to remote research stations (`<loc_customer>`) and retrieve climate data modules (`<demand_backhaul>`). Missions must finish within `<time_limit>` hours to avoid darkness or extreme cold. Routes terminate at temporary ice depots for data upload, ensuring no return to origin depots until all payloads are secured.

title: Meal Kit Delivery and Empty Container Collection Network
content: A meal kit subscription service operates from multiple regional distribution centers (MD) to serve urban and suburban customers. Delivery vehicles (C) transport pre-packed meals to subscribers’ homes (linehaul) and then collect empty reusable containers from prior deliveries (backhaul). Routes must prioritize deliveries before pickups (B), ending at the final collection point (O). To ensure freshness and operational efficiency, all routes must be completed within an 8-hour window (L), balancing vehicle capacity (C) between outbound supplies and inbound returns.

title: Industrial Facility Sanitation and Waste Retrieval
content: A specialized sanitation firm manages multiple regional depots (MD) to service industrial facilities. Vehicles (C) first deliver bulk cleaning chemicals and supplies (linehaul) to factories, then collect hazardous waste materials (backhaul) for disposal. Routes are designed as open paths (O), concluding at the last waste pickup location, with a strict 10-hour duration limit (L) to comply with worker safety regulations. Capacity constraints (C) require careful balancing of outbound chemical loads and inbound waste volumes.

title: Outdoor Adventure Gear Rental and Return Logistics
content: A mountain resort operates from several rental hubs (MD) to provide camping gear and equipment to hikers (linehaul). After use, customers return gear to designated drop-off points, which are then collected by the same vehicles (backhaul). Routes must first deliver gear to remote trailheads (linehaul) before backtracking to gather returns (B), ending at the final collection site (O). A 12-hour operational window (L) ensures timely service for day-trippers while adhering to vehicle capacity (C) limits for both gear delivery and retrieval.

title: Curbside Recycling Container Deployment and Retrieval
content: A municipal recycling firm uses multiple depots (MD) to deploy empty recycling bins (linehaul) to residential neighborhoods and collect filled containers (backhaul). Vehicles (C) must first distribute bins before returning along optimized paths to retrieve waste (B), with routes terminating at the last pickup location (O). All operations must conclude within a 6-hour window (L) to meet municipal regulations and maximize fleet efficiency, while ensuring bins and waste loads stay within capacity limits.

title: Trade Show Booth Setup and Dismantling Logistics
content: A trade show organizer coordinates with multiple regional warehouses (MD) to deliver modular booth materials (linehaul) to event venues and later dismantle and collect equipment (backhaul). Vehicles (C) first assemble exhibits, then retrieve disassembled components, with routes ending at the final dismantling site (O). A strict 8-hour workday (L) ensures timely setup and teardown, while capacity constraints (C) require precise balancing of outbound materials and inbound dismantled parts.

title: Medical Trial Supply Distribution and Sample Retrieval Network
content: Pharmaceutical companies must deliver clinical trial medications to hospitals (linehaul) while collecting patient blood samples (backhaul) for analysis. Multiple regional depots (MD) coordinate this process, ensuring vehicles first distribute medications before collecting samples to maintain chain-of-custody protocols. Routes must stay within strict duration limits (L) to preserve sample viability, and payloads (C) are constrained by vehicle capacity. Open routes end at the final sample collection site, optimizing efficiency without requiring return trips to depots.

title: Maritime Research Vessel Resupply and Ocean Sample Collection
content: Coastal research depots (MD) dispatch vessels to deliver equipment and provisions (linehaul) to offshore platforms while retrieving oceanographic samples (backhaul). Vessels must prioritize resupply before collecting samples (B) and adhere to voyage duration limits (L) dictated by fuel and crew endurance. Payload capacities (C) restrict both supplies and sample storage. Routes conclude at the furthest sampling site, minimizing redundant travel.

title: Disaster Zone Temporary Shelter Setup and Debris Removal
content: After a hurricane, relief teams from multiple depots (MD) distribute temporary shelters (linehaul) to affected areas and collect debris (backhaul). Vehicles first deliver shelters (B requirement) before hauling rubble, balancing payload capacities (C) for both materials. Routes must operate within time constraints (L) to accelerate recovery, ending at the final debris collection point. Open routes eliminate unnecessary return trips to depots.

title: Precision Agriculture Drone Swarms
content: Distributed depots (MD) deploy drone swarms to deliver fertilizers/pesticides (linehaul) to farms and collect soil samples (backhaul). Each drone must complete deliveries before sampling (B), adhering to battery life limits (L) and payload capacities (C) for both supplies and samples. Routes terminate at the farthest sampling location to maximize coverage while avoiding mid-mission depot returns.

title: Urban Electric Scooter Redistribution and Maintenance Parts Cycle
content: A mobility startup uses multi-city depots (MD) to redistribute scooters to high-demand zones (linehaul) and collect damaged units (backhaul). Vehicles first deliver scooters before retrieving faulty ones (B), constrained by scooter-loading capacities (C). Routes must fit within shift durations (L) to ensure operational efficiency, ending at the last collection point without returning to depots.
